title: Julie Bishop urges China to pressure North Korea over suspected nuclear test
content: Australia has urged China to use its influence over North Korea to seek to rein in the regime’s “provocative and dangerous behaviour” after a suspected nuclear test. The foreign affairs minister, Julie Bishop, joined the United States and South Korea in expressing scepticism about North Korea’s claims to have successfully tested a miniaturised hydrogen bomb on Wednesday, saying it had exaggerated its technical prowess in the past. But Bishop said Kim Jong-un’s regime was escalating tensions on the Korean peninsula and proving a threat to regional stability and international security. Asked on ABC radio about the notion that Pyongyang could make a nuclear weapon small enough to fit on a missile that could reach Australia, Bishop said this was “the concern of countries like Australia” while cautioning that “the details of the precise weapon are not yet established”. As the United Nations security council considers ratcheting up sanctions on North Korea, Bishop emphasised the role that China should play, even as she acknowledged limits to Beijing’s influence over Pyongyang. “China will be key to ensuring that the sanctions are imposed and that the relationship between Chinese companies and individuals and North Korea doesn’t lessen the impact of the sanctions,” she said on Thursday. “China is clearly frustrated with North Korea’s behaviour, it has been for some time, and I think there’s been a cooling of relations between Beijing and Pyongyang, but nevertheless China is its closest ally, its only friend if you like, and China does have considerable influence over North Korea. “[The influence is] perhaps not as much as the international community would wish, but nevertheless as a neighbour and as a friend of North Korea, China can continue to exert pressure to ensure that the leader of North Korea abides by international norms and progresses the denuclearisation of the weapons program.” North Korean state media announced the fourth nuclear test on Wednesday after seismologists from other countries said they had detected a 5 magnitude earthquake that could have been caused by an explosion. The television announcer said the country would “not give up a nuclear program as long as the United States maintains its stance of aggression”. North Korean claims about the device have not been independently verified. The White House said initial analysis was “not consistent with the claim the regime has made a successful hydrogen bomb test”. Some experts have suggested the activity was similar to a 2013 test involving a less-powerful atomic fission device. Australia’s main political parties have expressed a similar message of concern about North Korea’s nuclear program. The acting leader of the Labor opposition, Penny Wong, said the testing of a hydrogen bomb would be “a clear and serious violation” of UN security council resolutions. “North Korea’s nuclear program is a threat to global security and presents a major threat to peace in north-east Asia,” Wong said. “We condemn it in the strongest possible terms.”
